ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Increased my Chinese ability
I gained more knowledge about Chinese grammar and culture.
Ive learned a lot of new Chinese characters and grammar
Learned more grammar, vocabulary, and how to discuss more everyday/difficult topics about society
I improved my Chinese reading, writing, and speaking abilities. My vocabulary and sentence structure greatly improved, as did the logical construction of my essays.
Furthered my knowledge of Chinese vocabulary, sentence structures, and grammar
I became much more proficient and comfortable using intermediate Chinese to express my thoughts and opinions.

I improved my Chinese-speaking skills, as well as learned how to read and write new Chinese characters. I also learned about Chinese culture and pertinent social and political issues experienced in China.
Understanding and further proficiency in Mandarin Chinese writing, reading, listening, and speaking.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Cheng Li
No real weaknesses

The strength is that it is a very structured and well organized class. I felt that the content was the perfect level of difficulty. I took the class with Li Laoshi and felt that he made the learning experience very engaging and exciting. The biggest weakness of the course is that I felt a lot of the homework was overly repetitive and not intellectually stimulating.
Strength: High engagement and fun teachers. Weakness: There are assignments pretty much every single day, which was tedious, but they werent particularly hard (felt too much like busywork).

NO WEAKNESSES. Li Laoshi is awesome. Super engaging, helpful, he makes sure you are learning and gives you the opportunity to speak alot. He wants the best for his students and really cares about our progress!!

I thought the course was well structured. As a language course, it made sense to meet daily and review our textbook and discuss the lesson. The weekly discussion posts were very interesting and I learned more about Chinese culture beyond just language. I think it would have been helpful to have more of the cultural aspect incorporated and to have more class discussions.

Overall, the class is amazing and fun. Cheng Li was an awesome teacher and the material was very detailed and structured. The only thing is the topics that we talked about from the textbook is are sometimes outdated and not relevant to real world situations.

Strengths: amazing teacher who really cared about his students and his students' success! Super supportive.

Weaknesses: virtual format really is not the same.

Although every online course has its pitfalls, this course was the most engaging and productive of all the courses I've taken this academic year. The mix of learning formats - lecture, discussion, grammar practice, debates, watching videos - kept the course interesting throughout the semester.
I think the course is very focused on memorization at this level of Chinese and it could benefit by more breaking down of how to better understand the construction of Chinese characters.

Strong teachers facilitate in-class student engagement, with is vital for language learning. I appreciated the class' well thought out structure. The minimal weaknesses, such as difficulties finding time to converse with students in the language, were due to online class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Was very engaging. No complaints
I think breakout rooms were very nice because they helped me form a more genuine relationship with some of my classmates.

I thought the engagement was well donebreakout rooms in Zoom helped facilitate individual conversations and improve speaking skills; having the powerpoint in front of us to follow along with was also helpful.
I felt like the virtual seminar is engaging as it would be in an in person seminar.

Daily tests and rigor of pre-pandemic Chinese was not replicated during the virtual classes. Therefore, it was easier to slip between the cracks and fall behind. But conversely, this wasn't necessarily a bad thing because the additional flexibility definitely improved the students' mental health.
All of it was amazing, I think that it was really interesting how the academic environment was reflected rather well in the small seminar zoom meetings.
My teacher prompted us individually to read the sentences and grammar structures on-screen aloud. This enabled me and the rest of the class be on top of the material and virtually engage.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes -- this is one of the most fastest and most effective ways to rapidly increase your Chinese ability in reading, writing, speaking, and understanding
Yes, I think knowing how to speak and write Chinese is a great life skill. All the professors in this department are amazing as well!
Yes. You really get to understand Chinese better
YES you have to take chinese it's great to learn not only the language on a more in depth level but also about the culture and traditions of the people and country
Its a great course to improve your Chinese language abilities.

Yes, if you would like to improve your chinese abilities. Engagement is very high so you can expect your speaking and listening abilities to improve a lot. Tests are not too bad if you study the vocabulary and practice sentence structures.
Yes! If you want to improve your Chinese, there is no better way than live with an instructor and daily practice.

I would absolutely recommend this course to other students. Although it is rigorous in its workload and very fast-paced, every assignment and in-class exercise serves a purpose in bettering your understanding of the Chinese language and culture. CHNS 042 was one of the most rewarding courses I've taken.
Yes, but only if you are truly interested in Chinese. The workload is no joke and even some heritage students will struggle.
You'll spend a lot of time on this class learning the material; however, the teacher's are really quite good and care about your development.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Breakout rooms for 1-on-1 discussion
Zoom
We had tests, essays, oral presentations, discussions, discussion posts, and regular homework and dictation assignments.
Virtual seminars with occasional break out rooms for discussions
none
There was also a tutorial session on zoom.
Weekly 1 on 1 Tutorial Sessions
